We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators has an initial object, which is the space of complex-valued functions on the real line with the inner product given by the integral. This provides a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive polar capsule, is unknown. Here we report the results of a comparative genomics study of two myxozoans and a cnidarian, which show that myxozoans are a sister group to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, P. hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Less)

The study of the mechanisms of action of viruses is of great interest to understand the mechanisms of action of pathogens and to develop strategies to combat them. Here we describe a mechanism of action of a virus that is able to block the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the antiviral response.

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future, even if the mean yield increases. This increase in variability will be especially high in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries, where it will affect the stability of global grain trade and international grain prices, especially for the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which different species of large mammals partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in ecosystems. However, the degree to which different species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in diet. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven species of African herbivores, and that these species differed in diet composition even when they were matched in size and digestive physiology. Our results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the marine environment. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris in the ocean. Our results point at the importance of nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered.

The study of the history of the solar system is one of the most important goals of astrophysics. The history of the solar system is also one of the most important goals of geochemistry. The study of the history of the solar system is also one of the most important goals of geochemistry.

We show that the global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, with the motorized fleet increasing by a factor of 10. This has been driven by the expansion of the powered-artisanal fleet, which has increased its share of the global fleet from 10% to 68% between 1950 and 2015. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also one of the most plastic. We show that the ability to reproduce is also one of the most plastic.

The study of the mechanisms of neurodegeneration in multiple system atrophy (MSA) is hampered by the rarity of the disease and the lack of biomarkers. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-synuclein in a mouse model of MSA. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in MSA and opens the way to the development of a clinical trial.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues. It is the first line of defense against pathogens and is the primary regulator of blood flow, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells and is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources. This paper describes the nature of the communication network between the endothelial cells and the properties of the network. The findings reveal that the communication network is effective in the interaction of the cells and robust in the communication between the cells. The findings also reveal that the communication network is effective in the interaction of the cells and robust in the communication between the cells.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and accessible data is likely to persist for some time. We describe the design and operation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We believe that the COVIDcast API will be useful to policy makers, epidemiological modelers, and researchers in the United States and beyond.

The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel’s pore and is responsible for the selectivity of the ion’s passage. The selectivity filter is in a deep, nonconductive state in the closed and inactivated state and in a conductive, open state in the activated state. We have shown that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microorganisms that is essential for the health of the host. The role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood, but they are known to be present in the digestive tracts of herbivores. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products, which could be used as a source of therapeutics. We identified a large number of genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for natural products, and we detected a number of natural products in the culture supernatants of four representative anaerobic fungi. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products, which could be used to develop new therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

This work is devoted to the design of mechanical structures that can realize any desired response under large deformation. The proposed approach is based on the synthesis of composite structures with multiple material phases, which are optimally designed to achieve the target responses. The synthesized structures are then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed approach can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major target for the development of drugs for the treatment of anemia. In this study, we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, which is involved in the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway, is expressed in the erythroid lineage and plays a role in the regulation of hemoglobin expression.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. We report here that the inhibition of mTORC1 sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, through the induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1). This finding provides a potential mechanism for the development of a combination therapy that may be useful in the treatment of cancer.

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers, which are associated with the development of heart failure. Our study shows that the three major classes of LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells, which in turn promotes vascular remodeling. Our findings indicate that LCCBs are not the most appropriate drugs for treating hypertension in patients with advanced cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The predicted best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics and to the improvement of the antibiotic treatment of infections caused by resistant pathogens.

We introduce a new deep learning architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The proposed architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful for many image-processing problems.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi ecosystem is a classic example of the effects of climate variability on the distribution and diversification of species. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind, 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability from Lake Malawi, East Africa. Our results show that the evolution of the lake was strongly influenced by changes in the effective moisture of the climate system, and that the evolution of the lake and the fish species that inhabit it is a direct response to climate change.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has important consequences for sleep, circadian phase, and alertness the next morning. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1,300-y period of abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered this cooling. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the Younger Dryas sediments is consistent with the osmium in the crust of the Earth, and that the magnetic grains and microspherules in the sediments are of terrestrial origin. The spherules in the sediments are also of terrestrial origin, and their source is in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still to be determined. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be ameliorated by the presence of Tregs.

The order Coleoptera is arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We present a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of beetles, which resolves the evolutionary history of the group and provides insights into the diversification of the most speciose group of animals.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work provides a promising approach for the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

This study is about the evolution of technology, and in particular, the evolution of the ability of technology to evolve. We show that the size of the population of individuals that can learn from the actions of others has a limited effect on the evolution of technology.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE E4 allele increases AD risk by ∼12-fold, whereas APOE E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that the amount of C1q protein accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration, is highly dependent on APOE alleles. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. The inner core is a solid sphere of iron that is about 120 km in diameter and 15 km in thickness. It is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth. The formation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. In this paper, we show that the bcc phase of iron is more stable than the hcp phase under the conditions of the inner core. This result provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox, which has been a long-standing problem in geophysics.

This study provides evidence that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers. This finding is consistent with the idea that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers. The study also provides evidence that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might be a target for treatment of marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are among the most complex and mysterious aspects of the human mind. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world can predict the neural responses of human observers to sentences with similar accuracy. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing is a fundamental mechanism in the brain’s language system.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the use of standard optimization algorithms, which are not well-conditioned. We introduce a new algorithm, FIRENET, which is stable and converges to a solution with high probability. We prove that only a small number of layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. The scientific community has been working hard to understand the virus and its spread, and to develop effective countermeasures. This paper is about a classic psychological experiment that has been cited more than 1,000 times in the scientific literature, but which has been overlooked by the scientific community. It is about the importance of critical thinking, and about the dangers of falling prey to cognitive biases.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and is still with us today. We have sequenced the genome of a patient with leprosy, and compared it with that of the causative agent of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae. We find that the two organisms are more similar than expected by chance, and that they have retained many of the same functions, despite having been separated by millions of years of evolution.

The dynamics of quantum entanglement and entropy is a central topic in quantum many-body physics. However, the dynamics of entanglement is not trivial to compute, and the only exact result is for noninteracting systems. Here, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in interacting systems can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is a regime where the system is isolated and the only interaction is with the vacuum. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 500,000 people in the United States and more than 5.5 million people worldwide. The only vaccine currently available in the United States is the Pfizer–BioNTech vaccine, which requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. This vaccine is effective, but it is not a cure, and it is not available to everyone. We describe a vaccine that is effective, available, and can be mass produced.

Plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a better understanding of the history of plague and its vectors, which is important for the development of effective control strategies.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density, which is the brain’s computational power, has been neglected. This study fills this gap by using the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been the subject of intense investigation, but the results have been mixed. We have found that TRAP1 is required for the survival of cells that have acquired oncogenic mutations, and that it is necessary for the invasiveness of tumor cells. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a protein that is involved in many cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cytokinesis. It is known to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanism is critical for ADF/cofilin to sever highly connected filament networks, such as those found in cell-cell junctions. Our results provide a mechanism for how ADF/cofilin can be so efficient at severing filaments in cells.

This study provides evidence that the effects of glucose and fructose on brain and behavior are quite different. These findings have implications for our understanding of the effects of sugar on the brain and body, and may help to explain the differences in the effects of sugar on weight gain in humans and animals.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We present a high-resolution genomic study of the Malagasy people, a population that has been isolated for a long time and that has a unique genetic signature. We show that the Malagasy people have a Bantu and an Austronesian ancestry, and that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several waves, with a recent demographic growth. We also show that the genetic structure of the Malagasy people is influenced by the geography of the island, and that the genetic diversity is shaped by a few centuries of human activity.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This is a major finding, because it suggests that the influence of others is not limited to the people we interact with in person, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis has been difficult to assess. Here, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in an mRNA codon can have a profound effect on translation. We show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can reduce the rate of translation and can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on the rate of translation and the decoding of the mRNA sequence. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more social and economic engagement, and less loneliness. This finding is consistent across a wide range of sociodemographic characteristics, and it is also associated with positive changes in outcomes over a 4-y period. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and gerontology. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of body size in mammals is one of the most important and least understood patterns in biology. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of this virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature has been a long-standing mystery. We show that this temperature-dependent growth phenotype is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of the common cold virus and for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

This work demonstrates that the type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor for the detection of surfaces. This is an important finding because it shows that the pili are involved in the sensing of the environment, and in the regulation of the expression of virulence factors.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades, and the use of insecticides in particular is associated with a high risk for the aquatic environment. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is based on a unique database of 838 studies from 73 countries. Our results show that the risk for the aquatic environment is high, and that the use of insecticides in agriculture is associated with a substantial risk for the biological integrity of global water resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the virus has been shown to be transmitted to animals, including deer. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive deer, and the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in deer at a time when human cases were increasing in Iowa. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and for the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems that are being caused, and the solutions that are needed.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide public health crisis. Here, we identify a previously unrecognized role for soluble and oligomeric amyloid-β (Aβ) in the initiation of the AD immune response. We show that neurons, which are the primary cell type affected in AD, are capable of producing a variety of immune factors, even in the absence of extracellular Aβ pathology. This neuron-derived inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and may be a significant contributor to the disease pathogenesis. Our findings provide a new perspective on the AD immune response and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in this region at least 100 y before the species was introduced into Europe. Our results suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. This work shows that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, proceeds through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The results are consistent with the idea that the folding of proteins is a multistep process.

We report on the discovery of a previously unknown role for the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH in the decapping of Np4-capped RNAs, which are known to accumulate in response to stress. We show that this enzyme, which is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress. Our results suggest that this enzyme, which is not known to decapp cap-dependent RNAs, is a critical component of the cellular response to stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is a key player in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolic product of arginine, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function during sepsis. Our results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study may also lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of other immune-related diseases.

The biomass of the biosphere is the sum of the masses of all living organisms. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Here, we provide a global census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life, which is the first of its kind.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronic and quantum applications. However, its properties are sensitive to defects, and it is difficult to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability, through strain engineering. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The study of the molecular mechanisms of action of antimicrobial peptides is of great interest to the scientific community and to the pharmaceutical industry. Here, we report the structural and functional characterization of a unique antifungal peptide, NCR044, which is a member of a large family of nodule-specific cysteine-rich peptides. We show that this peptide is highly diverse in sequence and exhibits potent antifungal activity against plant fungal pathogens.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the contributions of the sexes are not equal. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the viability of sperm, suggesting that the female reproductive tract may play a role in the process of fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large, multidomain protein that binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) to promote platelet adhesion and coagulation. The A1 domain in VWF binds to GPIbα, and mutations in A1 cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches A1 and/or GPIbα to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD. The conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This is the first time that this conversion has been observed for a protein. (Read more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been a more challenging target, due to the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive catalog of human-associated viruses, with over 45,000 unique virus taxa, and over 100 gigabases of viral sequence. This database is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study will help to advance the field of microbiome research.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to investigate the ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for more than a century. Here we present a method for determining the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are also the targets of drugs. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the normal function of cells and are also involved in many diseases. In this study, we found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel has a unique type of slow inactivation, which is state-dependent and closed state-dependent. This study provides a new perspective on the mechanism of ion channel inactivation.

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide and is caused by the Plasmodium parasite. The parasite must overcome a number of barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC), the target of infection. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, which may facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronic and quantum applications. However, its properties are sensitive to defects, and it is difficult to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability, through strain engineering. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection is a long-standing and controversial issue. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the role of ambient humidity in the severity of influenza virus infection. They also suggest that the impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection may be species- and strain-dependent, and that the impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection may be species-dependent. These findings may help to improve our understanding of the impact of ambient humidity on the severity

The brain is thought to build its mental representation of a sentence word by word, but whether and how it does so is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a bottom-up parser that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is the first study to show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and cell fate. It is also involved in the control of cell proliferation and in the development of cancer. We show here that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which may allow for tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin.
This work provides a detailed description of the brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is a key process in the functioning of the global nitrogen cycle. However, the use of free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture is limited by the lack of a sustainable way to deliver the fixed nitrogen to the plant. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in communities that were most threatened by deforestation. Our results are consistent with the idea that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.
We show that the web of a spider is an acoustic antenna that can detect the presence of an acoustic wave. This is the first time that an animal has been shown to use its web as an acoustic antenna.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with no approved vaccine. We report the design, synthesis, and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-volume microbial production. This protein is highly immunogenic, and presentation of the protein on a virus-like particle reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered protein may be a useful component for a vaccine against COVID-19.
We report on the identification of a ligand for the ALK family of kinases, which is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex and poorly understood process. We present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes, which provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its relationship with its vector, the flea. Our results suggest that the plague lineage that gave rise to the disease was not highly diverse during the early stages of its development, and that the flea-adapted form of plague emerged later in the Bronze Age. These data provide a more complete picture of the early evolution of plague and its vector, and may help to shed light on the origins of this devastating disease. (Less)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The management of agricultural lands has been shown to be a major driver of the global carbon cycle. In this study, we show that the management of grasslands and pastures can be a powerful tool to mitigate climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of zoonotic spillover and the potential for emerging viruses to spread globally. We developed a framework to assess the risk of spillover and spread of viruses in animals to humans, and created a web tool to make this information publicly available. We used this tool to assess the risk of 887 viruses from 74,635 animals, and found that the majority of viruses with the greatest potential to spill over to humans are not yet known to be zoonotic. The SpillOver tool can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. This work provides a roadmap for future research and public health interventions to mitigate the threat of zoonotic viruses.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying the production of the color are not well understood. We show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a similar alkaloid in the red nectar of hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae, suggesting that this trait is convergent in two different vertebrate-pollinated species. Our findings provide evidence for the existence of a small number of compounds that are likely to underlie the evolution of this type of adaptation. This work also demonstrates the importance of studying the chemistry of nectar, which is a reward that is essential for the survival of many species. (Less)

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions, but the role of women in these processes has been largely overlooked. Here we present the genome of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived in the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that these women had a very high genetic diversity, and that some of them had an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results highlight the importance of women in shaping the genetic landscape of Europe, and the need for more studies of women from this period.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. Our results show that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, and its genetic relatives, pose a threat to human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. (Show more)

This study demonstrates the feasibility of using next-generation sequencing to identify pathogens in a resource-scarce setting. We show that mNGS can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, which are responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. We also show that mNGS can be used to identify the presence of HIV, which is not routinely tested for in this setting. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of mNGS in resource-scarce settings, and the identification of pathogens that are responsible for undifferentiated fevers. This study also provides a foundation for the use of mNGS in the surveillance of emerging pathogens.

The human genome is replicated in a single-stranded template-directed manner, which is a unique and important feature of eukaryotes. This process is carried out by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the PCNA sliding clamp. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a unique insight into the mechanism of lagging strand replication and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer and other diseases.

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in science. In this work, we report the development of an RNA-based polymerase that can replicate RNA, amplify RNA, and synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including functional RNA. This work represents a major step toward the development of an in vitro RNA-based cell.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a method for measuring the physical appearance of neighborhoods that can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical patients with COVID-19 were analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab was assessed. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical patients with COVID-19, and the mortality was reduced.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to sense and respond to copper is important for their interactions with the environment and with other organisms. Here we describe the role of a biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus, which produces a family of isocyanide compounds that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. We also show that these compounds have antimicrobial properties and can mediate interactions between fungi and bacteria. These findings suggest that the xan gene cluster is a previously unknown source of fungal metabolites that can influence the balance of copper and other metals in the cell and that can mediate interactions with other organisms. The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, in a sample of laminated mudstone from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a mineral that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism, and the presence of this mineral in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment is consistent with the presence of a “Lake” in the past. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in a sample of laminated mudstone is consistent with the presence of a silicic volcanic source in the past. The presence of amorphous precipitated silica, and possibly the crystalline magnetite (otherwise detrital) in a sample of laminated mudstone is consistent with the presence of a silicic volcanic source in the past. The presence of post lithification fracture/vein fill anhydrous sulfate in a sample of laminated mudstone is consistent with the presence of a silicic volcanic source in the past.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals, and the frequency of late-spring frosts (LSFs) is increasing in many regions of the world. We show that the geographic distribution of LSFs is linked to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees, and that the resistance strategies of trees are linked to their performance in common gardens. Our findings reveal that the regions in which LSFs are common today will be the most vulnerable to increasing frost damage in the future. Our results can help decision-makers in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a recently discovered subset of CD4+ T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of these cells are unknown. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors, and that these cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This work provides insight into the mechanisms of Th17 cell development and their role in inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, which can be used to study the disease and screen for therapeutics.

This study provides a unique example of a pathogen using an arthropod antibacterial protein to influence the tick microbiota, which in turn influences the pathogen’s ability to colonize the tick. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the evolution of the tail is important for understanding the origin of flight and the evolution of the modern avian body plan. Here, we describe a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians, and show that this group of birds was more diverse than previously thought.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that the water vapor in the stratosphere increases with the temperature in the troposphere, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

The color of animals is an important component of their communication and camouflage. In this study, we describe a mechanism of color regulation in anurans (frogs and toads) that is present in multiple species and has evolved multiple times.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with the emergence of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. We also show that ALKBH5 overexpression increases the proportion of breast cancer cells that are tumorigenic, and that knockdown of ALKBH5 expression in breast cancer cells reduces their capacity for tumor initiation. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we present a method that is simple, noninvasive, and objective, and that can be used to identify the animal origin of parchment. We show that the use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is not necessary to sustain the production of thousands of pocket Bibles in the 13th century.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the causes and mechanisms of the event, and for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill hypotheses. Here we present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb zircon dates from five volcanic ash beds.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also show that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides a better understanding of the role of RORα in intestinal homeostasis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for IBD. (Show more)

We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 in complex with the human ACE2 receptor. We find that the receptor binding domain of the spike glycoprotein contains a single mutation (D614G) that is present in the currently circulating variants of concern. We show that this mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike glycoprotein, which may facilitate receptor binding and viral entry. Our results provide insight into the mechanisms of viral entry and may help to inform the design of future vaccines and therapeutics.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We project that the pandemic will result in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, the first decline since 2003, and a decline in life expectancy at age 65 y of 0.87 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

We show that the effects of fire on climate are more complex than previously thought. We find that, although climate change has already driven an increase in global fire activity, human demography has suppressed it, and that this trend is likely to continue. This has the potential to reduce the warming caused by human emissions, although the magnitude of this effect depends on the strength of the climate–fire feedback. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to consider the effects of fire in climate models and climate policy.

This study shows that the delivery of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the dynamic stability of a symbiotic relationship. We show that the squid Euprymna scolopes, which is colonized by a bioluminescent symbiont, can regulate the provision of chitin to the symbiont, which in turn, is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of symbiosis.

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. This method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning and can be applied to any domain. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe.
We provide evidence that a densovirus is the cause of asteroid mass mortality. This is the first report of a densovirus in asteroids, and the first report of a virus in the order Ophiuroidea.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. We show here that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the IL1RAP-targeting antibody used in this study can be used to target IL-1 signaling, which is important for the growth of AML cells. Thus, the IL1RAP-targeting antibody described here has the potential to be used in combination with other therapies to treat AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian people, who settled in the islands of the Pacific, are found. We show that the Malagasy people are the result of a complex history of migration and admixture, with a recent settlement of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. Our results show that the genetic structure of the Malagasy is the result of a combination of processes, including the recent admixture, the sex bias of the admixture, and the geographic distribution of the admixture. These results are important for understanding the human history of Madagascar and for the study of the human population structure in the Indian Ocean. They also provide a framework for the study of the human history of the Pacific. (Less)

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate gene expression. In this study, we describe a dual-function RNA that encodes a protein and modulates carbon utilization. The RNA is found to base pair with two different promoters, one of which is required for growth in galactose. The protein, which is membrane-associated, interacts with one of the two enzymes that are regulated by the RNA. The protein also interferes with the RNA’s ability to repress the expression of two other genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work provides a promising approach for the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

Crop condition is a key indicator of the state of the agricultural economy, and is used by farmers, policy makers, and the general public to assess the impact of weather and climate on crop production. However, the current system for monitoring crop condition is based on a survey of crop experts, which is prone to human error and is only available at the end of the growing season. In this work, we show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey can be used to monitor crop condition in real time, and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our work demonstrates the potential of harnessing the power of the “people as sensors” network to improve the accuracy of agricultural monitoring, and provides a framework for the development of new systems for monitoring the state of the agricultural economy.

Language is a highly complex system that is still poorly understood. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rates of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The response of soil respiration to climate warming is a key uncertainty in our understanding of the global carbon cycle. In this study, we provide the most comprehensive synthesis of the literature to date on the temperature response of soil respiration to climate warming. Our analysis reveals that the response of soil respiration to climate warming is highly variable across biomes, with no consistent pattern of acclimation. Our results highlight the importance of understanding the temperature response of soil respiration in a range of ecosystems, as this information is critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of eukaryotes. Here, we show that the transition to parasitic lifestyles, which is a key event in the evolution of eukaryotes, is linked to a relaxation of selection pressure on the plastid genome. Our findings provide a new perspective on the evolution of the plastid genome and the origin of eukaryotes.

The impact of climate change on droughts is a major concern for water managers and the general public. In this study, we show that the probability of a prolonged drought in South Africa increased by a factor of five to six in the 2015–2017 period, and that this probability will increase to 80% by the end of the century under a high-emission scenario. These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results also show that the current drought in SSA is not unprecedented in the instrumental record, and that it is likely to be repeated in the future under high-emission scenarios. This study provides a valuable contribution to the scientific community and to water managers, who are currently facing the consequences of the current drought in South Africa. It also provides a basis for further research on the impact of climate change on droughts in SSA.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are not understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb.

Photosynthesis is the primary source of energy on Earth. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is mediated by the photosynthetic pigments, chlorophyll and bacteriochlorophyll. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage. Our study provides a better understanding of the roles of ASK1 in glial cells and suggests that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation.
