California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased over the past few decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis, and the identification of the causal genes is a major challenge. Here, we show that the reversal-learning task, which is a measure of behavioral flexibility, is a useful tool for identifying the converging functions of autism-risk genes.

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights the potential for more positive content, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of Ca2+ signaling in the immune system, and is also involved in a variety of other cellular processes. Here, we report that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or in the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 can lead to a spectrum of phenotypes, including hematological abnormalities, immune dysfunction, and muscle disease. These data expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the presence of a defined population of neurons, and that this spreading is dependent on the internalization of aggregates. We also show that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous, and that this spreading can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis. Finally, we show that the spread of aggregates requires active release and uptake of aggregates. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and the potential for MTX to be used as a therapeutic target. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one of the most common genetic alterations in cancer cells is the loss of function of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and show that they are effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the cytotoxicity of SHMT inhibitors in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These findings provide a basis for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics, and for the identification of a metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous motor neuron disease with no known cause or cure. Here, we show that the proteins that are coaggregated in the brains and spinal cords of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results provide a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The study of Montsechia, an early aquatic angiosperm, is of great interest because it is the first plant to be recovered from the Cretaceous. The study of Montsechia, together with the study of other plants and animals from the same deposits, has led to a better understanding of the evolution of the first plants and the origin of the first terrestrial plants and animals.

The study of ancient viruses is of great interest for understanding the evolution of viruses and the impact of viruses on human evolution. Here we present the first ancient B19V sequences, which are of great interest for understanding the evolution of B19V and the impact of B19V on human evolution.

We show that the acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y is not due to measurement noise but is instead consistent with a climate-change–driven acceleration. This result is consistent with the findings of the IPCC AR5 and shows that the observed acceleration is not due to measurement noise but is instead consistent with a climate-change–driven acceleration.

Pain is a major public health problem, and the number of Americans reporting pain is rising. However, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in providing a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction pathway of a key enzyme intermediate. This work highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions, and it provides a detailed picture of the reaction pathway of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate in tryptophan synthase. This work also demonstrates the ability of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide information about the chemical environment of the enzyme cofactor, which is critical for understanding the reaction mechanism. This work is a step toward the goal of understanding enzyme mechanisms by combining NMR and crystallography. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment, and the disease has a high mortality rate. We show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is approved for use in other diseases, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

This study shows that the delivery of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent symbiont. This glycan is released by the squid’s immune cells, which migrate into the symbiont’s habitat, and is catabolized by the symbiont. This glycan delivery is timed to occur at night, when the symbiont is most active, and is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of symbiosis. (Show more)

This research is about the importance of teachers’ mindsets about discipline. It is about the importance of the relationships between teachers and students. It is about the importance of the classroom as a place where students learn to be good citizens. It is about the importance of the classroom as a place where students learn to be good citizens.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain unknown. Here, we report that the presence of alkylation can lead to transcriptional stalling, which is dependent on the RNA polymerase II (pol II) fidelity checkpoint. We further show that the presence of alkylation can lead to multiple transcriptional bypass routes, which are dependent on the pol II fidelity checkpoint. These results provide important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis. This work also provides a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of DNA repair and mutagenesis. This work is expected to provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of DNA repair and mutagenesis.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We show that sequential proteolysis of MERS-CoV S proteins is required for virus infection, and that the first cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection. These findings may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

This paper provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can lead to a proportional increase in sales of 60% or more. This is a large effect, and it is achieved with a simple change to the catering system, with no need for complex behavioral interventions. The results are robust to a range of potential confounding factors, and the effect is concentrated among diners with the lowest levels of vegetarian meal selection. The results are consistent with the idea that changing the physical environment in which people make decisions can lead to behavior change, and they suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian options available in catering outlets could be a simple and effective way to improve population health and protect the environment.

The cell surface proteome, the surfaceome, is the interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in oncogenic breast epithelial cells. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step in the development of a systems-level understanding of the role of the cell surface proteome in cancer.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the molecular basis of the disease and the mechanisms of viral spread. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. Our results show that SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 forms a unique dimeric structure, which may be important for immune evasion and spread. These results provide a molecular basis for the unique properties of the SARS-CoV-2 virus and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major environmental stressor that is used to study the mechanisms of edema and neuroprotection. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in the rat brain, and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1. We also show that this process is mediated by the up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) in astrocytes, which increases the influx of water into the brain, and that this is mediated by the activation of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes. Finally, we show that the up-regulation of AQP4 is necessary for the edema induced by hypoxia. These results provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. (Show more)

We live in an age of big data, in which the size of the data sets is growing much faster than our ability to analyze them. This paper describes a new way of analyzing big data, based on the idea of “selective inference.” This is the idea that, when we have found some associations in our data, we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the remaining associations. We illustrate the new approach in the context of forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We believe that selective inference will be a major advance in the analysis of big data.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of organs, such as the liver. However, the generation of vascular networks is difficult to achieve in vitro and in vivo. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells (ECs) from human fibroblasts, which can be used for the generation of vascular networks.

We report on the discovery of a third class of RTKs, which are named “augmentor” RTKs. We show that augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, which are a type of photoreceptor in the zebrafish retina. We also show that the augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores in the zebrafish eye and in the skin.

The role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function has been extensively studied. However, the function of STING in β-cells and insulin target tissues remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired GSIS, leading to glucose intolerance. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasionally for severe pandemics. The packaging of the viral genome is a key step in the assembly of the virions, and the existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We show that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses is limited by the lack of conservation of this interaction. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherogenic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. In this study, we identified a critical role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerosis and may lead to the development of a therapeutic strategy to prevent atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the natural landscape for millennia. However, in the last 150 y, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially. We show that the expansion of the fire niche in the United States is largely due to human activities, and that human-caused wildfires are now dominant in the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire and associated hazards should focus on reducing the human-caused fire niche.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a method for measuring the physical appearance of neighborhoods that can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500.

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a direct consequence of the altered nutrient cycling that occurs prior to the onset of bleaching. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn, trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the development of cancer therapies.

Chemotherapy is an important component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to treatment is not universal. We show that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, and survive treatment with paclitaxel. We also show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with a humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody, cirmtuzumab, repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, treatment of PDX-bearing mice with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The timing of the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most debated aspects of the last deglaciation. Here we show that a series of volcanic eruptions, which occurred exactly at the time of the onset of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a climate change that was similar to that observed in Antarctica after the recovery from the Mount Pinatubo eruption.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that inland fisheries are a critical source of protein for the poor and undernourished, and that these populations are particularly reliant on rivers in regions where they are already threatened by other stressors. Our data can be used to assess the impacts of fisheries on biodiversity and to identify areas where fisheries management can improve food security. Our results highlight the need for more effective conservation and management of freshwater fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles.

We report a form of regeneration in the nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is linked to a form of ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, and the study of recombination in plants is therefore of fundamental importance. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we show that the pattern is similar to that in yeast and in mice.

The resting state of the brain is a complex phenomenon, which has been studied in the last decade using functional MRI. The results of this study show that the organization of the resting state networks is a function of the disease, and that this information can be used to assess the functional status of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for the stability and translation of mRNA. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally, and that only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of NAD+ in health and disease. (Read more)

The study of epigenetic mechanisms has been a major focus of research in the last decade. The results of this study show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences persist at certain loci in blood cells for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), and that these differences are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of the DCCT.
This study provides a better understanding of the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also shows that the gut microbiota is a promising target for the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, which are responsible for the aroma and contribute to the overall flavor. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not known, and the only known nitrogenous volatiles are derived from cysteine. Here we report the identification of a gene, SlTNH1, which is essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and opens the door to the development of improved varieties with enhanced aroma. (Less)

We show that the impacts of global warming on the functioning of ecosystems are likely to be exacerbated by biodiversity loss. This is because the additional impacts of warming on the thermal tolerance of species will result in a greater proportion of species being lost from communities, and because the remaining species will be less able to maintain ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of climate change and biodiversity loss in the management of ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub in the hippocampus, which is involved in spatial navigation and memory. The organization of MEC is critical for the formation of a spatial map in the hippocampus. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. Our results suggest that the organization of MEC is more complex than previously thought.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for the flowering of the host and the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine system of the brain is involved in movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigro system, which project to the striatum to form the classic nigrostriatal pathway, are part of a much larger system that includes the striosome–dendron bouquets. These are specialized integrative units within the nigro system that are likely to be affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. The striosome–dendron bouquets are formed by striosomal cells that receive input from cortical regions related to mood and motivation and that project to the striatum to form the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Given this input and output, they could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are all social creatures, and we all seek connection. We are also all busy, and we all have limited attention. We show that the speed at which we respond to others is a robust and honest signal of connection, and that this signal is used by others to gauge the quality of our social interactions.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. The SAN is a highly coordinated system, and the electrical activity of the SAN is regulated by multiple mechanisms. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a regulator of the electrical activity of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its role in plant physiology has been debated. Here, we show that Si accumulation in rice plants is beneficial in protecting against insect attack. We demonstrate that the accumulation of Si in rice plants is enhanced by jasmonic acid (JA), and that this interaction is important in mediating resistance to insect herbivores. Our results suggest that the beneficial effects of Si on plant resistance against insect herbivores are mediated by JA.

This study shows that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in murine macrophages. The results also reveal that the impact of alkylglycerol monooxygenase on the lipidome goes beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a highly complex system that is characterized by the ability to integrate and process information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rates of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

This work is a first step in the direction of using DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. The work details the design parameters of importance for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step towards the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

We show that the majority of the nutrients that fuel algal blooms in the coastal zone of Lake Michigan come from small streams that drain the surrounding landscape. Our findings have important implications for the management of coastal eutrophication, which is a major threat to the health of aquatic ecosystems worldwide. Our results suggest that the management of small streams may be an effective way to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a fluctuating environment. We find that the system can be driven to a steady state that is far from equilibrium, and that this behavior is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. Our results suggest that the presence of a fluctuating environment can lead to the emergence of a new type of nonequilibrium steady state, and that the dynamics of such systems may be biased toward states that are not in thermodynamic equilibrium with the environment.

This work offers a new perspective on the mechanisms of action of NMDAR-Abs, which are currently the only treatment for this devastating disease. We show that NMDAR-Abs can change the dynamics of the brain, and that this can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This work offers a new perspective on the mechanisms of action of NMDAR-Abs, which are currently the only treatment for this devastating disease.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system, and it is important to understand the mechanisms that drive these events. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was driven by a global warming and that the warming was linked to an increase in atmospheric CO2 and anoxia.

We show that the RSPO has had a positive impact on reducing deforestation in oil palm plantations in Indonesia. However, the impact of certification on forest loss is small, and the vast majority of forests remain in plantations that are not certified. We also show that certification has no impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having the desired impact on reducing deforestation, and that the RSPO needs to be more stringent in its requirements and more effective in its monitoring.

The exocyst complex is a large protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the release of many proteins from the trans-Golgi network. The exocyst complex is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered a small molecule that binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study. In this work, we investigate the effects of a polygenic sex determination system on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species.

The retina is a unique organ in that it is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species, one generated by photoreceptors and the other by the pigment epithelium. This study shows that the redox state of the retina is influenced by the intracellular Fe pool, which is in turn influenced by the levels of vitamin A adducts that are generated by photooxidation. These findings have implications for the understanding of the role of Fe in redox signaling and for the development of strategies to protect the retina from damage. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the study of their evolution is fundamental to understanding the functioning of the food web. However, the evolution of predators is often difficult to study, and the results are often difficult to interpret. Here we show that the evolution of predators can be understood by studying the evolution of their prey, and that the evolution of predators can be used to understand the evolution of their prey.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of the genus Homo.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one of the most common causes of death worldwide. In this work, we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and show that this vulnerability can be exploited to treat cancer.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by the fragmentation of forests. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need for further research on the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of modern agriculture, allowing for the expansion of arable land and food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
